thread.title: Pep: City may miss out on CL
thread.title_full: Pep: City may miss out on CL

title: Pep: City may miss out on CL
text:
Pep Guardiola admits Manchester City may miss out on Champions League By PA Sport Last Updated: 04/02/17 11:04pm Pep Guardiola's Manchester City are currently fifth in the Premier League heading into Sunday's clash at home to Swansea Pep Guardiola has admitted it is possible that Manchester City could miss out on next season's Champions League. 
City, having been tipped to challenge for the title this year, are fifth in the Premier League heading into the Super Sunday clash at home to Swansea City , live on Sky Sports 1 HD from 12.30pm. 
Victory would take them above Arsenal and Liverpool into third, but the battle for top-four positions is tight. Guardiola was appointed in the hope he could guide City towards Champions League glory and so missing out altogether wouldrepresent a severe blow to the club's ambitions. 
"It is possible that we won't qualify," said Guardiola. "Today we are not in the Champions League (positions). Man City vs Swansea Get Sky Sports Get a Sky Sports pass 
"But we are going to see at the end of the season and then you will see my impression (of it). Let us fight until the end. Let me try at least that - fight." 
City have played some of their best football for some time since being jolted into action by a 4-0 defeat at Everton last month. Upgrade now and watch Man City v Swansea on Sunday and get 8 Sky Sports channels! 
In the last three games, they have been highly impressive in a 2-2 draw with Tottenham and beaten Crystal Palace - in the FA Cup - and West Ham convincingly. In such form, they should be strong challengers for the top four. 
Key to their recent success has been the potency of an attack reinvigorated by the arrival of Gabriel Jesus and the improved form of Leroy Sane. 
Jesus, the £27m signing from Palmeiras, has shone in his first three games, while Sane - after a slow start since his £37m arrival last summer - has scored three goals in his last four appearances. Guardiola gave an unusual analogy to City's newest star Gabriel Jesus after their 4-0 win at West Ham in midweek 
The pair are 19 and 21 years old respectively and, combined with 22-year-old Raheem Sterling, City's attacking line is full of youthful promise. 
Guardiola's next challenge will be to freshen up his defence. All four of his senior full-backs - Pablo Zabaleta (32), Bacary Sagna (33), Gael Clichy (31) and Aleksandar Kolarov (31) - are among those who could make way at the end of the season. 
Guardiola said: "We realise that we have a lot of players over 30. For example, full-backs are 31, 32. 
"But they are so important. We cannot change absolutely everything in one season. I can understand how important Yaya (Toure), Kolarov or Gael are, or the personality from Pablo, in the locker room. 
"At the end, the heart and soul of the team are the old players, the people who know the club."
